evidence.dc:description: Fetal expression is pretty high between 10-20 weeks gestation.

dc:source.dc:abstract: As the most common form of developmental malformation affecting the heart and endothoracic great vessels, congenital heart disease (CHD) confers substantial morbidity and mortality as well as socioeconomic burden on humans globally. Aggregating convincing evidence highlights the genetic origin of CHD, and damaging variations in over 100 genes have been implicated with CHD. Nevertheless, the genetic basis underpinning CHD remains largely elusive. In this study, via whole-exosome sequencing analysis of a four-generation family inflicted with autosomal-dominant CHD, a heterozygous
dc:source.dc:creator: Wang Z
dc:source.dc:title: SMAD1 Loss-of-Function Variant Responsible for Congenital Heart Disease.

evidence.rdfs:label: NCBI Fetal expression (not from this PMID)

dc:description: SMAD1 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant congenital heart disease in 2020 (Lago-Docampo et al; PMID: 32934261). Six variants (missense, nonsense, frameshift) that have been reported in thirteen probands in four publications (PMIDs: 30578397, 32934261, 33007923, 35281600) are included in this curation. However, only two variants (nonsense, frameshift) were scored (PMIDs: 32934261, 35281600) as the other variants were only seen in isolated idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension cases and/or were too frequent in population databases. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss-of-function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence (NCBI fetal expression data). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship.This classification was approved by the ClinGen Congenital Heart Disease GCEP on the meeting date 5/13/2024 (SOP Version 10).
